author: Chris kitching
title: Daughter left in tears after receiving email from shop saying her dead mum 'has got it going on'
text:
News Daughter left in tears after receiving email from shop saying her dead mum 'has got it going on' Customers whose mums recently died say they were left devastated after opening the personalised email which contains a reference to the Fountains of Wayne song "Stacey's Mom" Share Hollie Carew (right) lost her mum Lyn to cancer just seven months ago (Photo: Mercury Press) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
An online shop has been blasted as "cruel" over a personalised Mother's Day email received by customers whose mums recently died. 
Very.co.uk received complaints after it sent a promotional email to thousands of subscribers, saying their mums "have got it goin' on" - a reference to the Fountains of Wayne song "Stacey's Mom". 
Hollie Carew, whose mum died of cancer just seven months ago, said she felt sick and burst into tears when she opened the email. 
At least two other customers, who are spending their first Mother's Day without their mums, say they were left devastated after reading the "insensitive" email from the clothing retailer, which addressed them by their first names. The personalised email spelled Hollie's first name wrong (Photo: Mercury Press) 
Shop Direct, which operates Very.co.uk, have apologised and said the email was "fully-intended to be light-hearted". Read More Families flee in terror as cheetah escapes from its enclosure at Kent safari park 
Hollie, from Leeds, complained to Very.co.uk after she received the email, which spelled her first name incorrectly, last Tuesday. 
The 33-year-old, who works for a dog daycare company, said: "It was the title of the email that caught my attention. It said 'Holly's mum has got it going on'. 
"I was like, 'what'?' I was shocked, and felt a bit sick, then I was really upset and started crying. 
"I was angry that they had actually said that. Because they had personalised the email for me it was even more of a shock." 
Hollie's mum Lyn Carew, 63, died of cancer in August last year, just weeks after she was diagnosed. 
She said: "It all happened really quickly, and we're still trying to sort things out now. It's all still very fresh and I'd only just started to think I was starting to deal with it about a month ago. Hollie says the email left her in tears (Photo: Mercury Press) 
"Christmas was really hard, then it was her birthday in January. We're still sorting things out with the solicitors and I was just starting to get on with things again. 
"This kind of reminder was the last thing I needed - a first Mother's Day without her is hard enough as it is. Read More 
"I saw that other people had also complained to Very.co.uk and been upset about it after me, so then I felt sure that I wasn't overreacting about it." 
Hollie said she wasn't satisfied with the company's response to her complaint. 
She said: "When I and others complained we only received a generic apology. There was no personal response. 
"We were asked to fill in a form, if we wished, that would remove us from the Very.co.uk email list. 
"That was just extra work for me to do after something that shouldn't have happened in the first place. 
"I would have liked a proper apology. It's given me a different impression of the company." The email contains a reference to a Fountains of Wayne song (Photo: Mercury Press) 
Customer James Mawdsley, 40, from Chester, Cheshire, was also left upset when he spotted the email in his inbox. 
James, whose mum died of cancer two years ago, also complained to Very.co.uk. Read More Murderer posts sick selfie of FEET from prison cell boasting of kicking schoolboy, 13, to death with them 
He said: "I was shocked to receive a message with the title, 'James's mum has got it goin' on'. 
"I thought it was really quite insensitive. I lost my mum quite recently and thought it was very strange to send an email with that title. 
"It was targeting me personally, which made it worse. Quite frankly I can't imagine many marketing managers approving an email like that. 
"I understand that it's Mother's Day and they want to promote it but what's wrong with something like 'Treat your mum on Mother's Day'?" 
A third customer complained to the company on social media, saying: "As if Mother's Day isn't hard enough to then receive an email with that title. At least one customer complained on social media (Photo: Mercury Press) 
"I totally understand the need for them to advertise Mother's Day but the title of the email was so insensitive." Read More Harrowing footage of 'ferocious' crash that killed schoolboy, 12, that heartbroken mum wants you to see 
A spokesperson for Shop Direct said: "We apologise sincerely for any distress we may have inadvertently caused to customers with this campaign. 
"We fully intended the email to be light-hearted, but we appreciate that a small number of people found it upsetting. 
"We'll learn from it and bear those learnings in mind for future campaigns." Like us on Facebook
